Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Medium: A Sparse Decomposition Framework for Complex System Design and Analysis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Large scale, pervasive communication systems are an important part of everyday life and, with the emergence of the Internet of Everything technology, are becoming an essential part of our infrastructure. Future communication systems necessitate significantly new design paradigms because they are large scale and involve a complex interaction of communications, "natural" (environmental) networks as well as control. The seamless management of a system of this complexity, interconnection, and scale is daunting. A fundamentally new approach is needed to tackle the issues of scale and complexity. The investigators are studying novel mathematical models for network design and optimization for systems of much larger size than those that are tractable with current methods. They are planning to demonstrate their utility on applications such as cognitive radio, wireless body area sensing networks and potentially models for bacterial populations. The new methods have the potential to impact the design and control of very general, large-scale networks such as biological, social networks and the SmartGrid.

This research develops a novel theoretical framework to address the challenges of large scale system design by analyzing, tracking, and controlling Markov processes over graphs associated with complex systems. The correlation induced in these large Markov chains is exploited via sparse approximation theory employing graph wavelets for representation. Typical complex systems induce an underlying sparsity that enables dimensionality reduction via compressed sensing-like schemes. This research develops new sparse techniques for formal modeling, analysis and optimization of large-scale systems that evolve temporally, by designing novel graph wavelets for directed graphs, in combination with new sparse approximation algorithms and control methods tailored to the complex systems for estimation, communication and control.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The introduction of sensing, communication and control in all manner of devices (cellphones, smart meters, smart appliances, autonomous vehicles, etc.) has created a cyberphysical network that offers both significant opportunities for the enhancement of the quality of life, but also significant complexity.  As such  cyberphysical systems necessitate significantly new design paradigms.  They are immense in size and involve a complex interaction of communication networks, "natural'' (environmental) networks as well as control. The seamless management of a system of this complexity, interconnection, and scale is daunting. A fundamentally new approach is needed to tackle the issues of scale and complexity.

 

We have developed a novel theoretical framework to address these challenges by analyzing, tracking, and controlling specific models for the random processes that both govern and emerge from these complex systems.  In particular, while the networks are large, they often admit a lower complexity description than is suggested by their complete description.  Just as harmonic analysis (Fourier transforms) allowed for the processing and compression of music and then images and video, there are new methods by which we can determine lower complexity descriptions of networks.  The new methods are based on graph signal processing. In particular, we have developed new sparse techniques can be developed for formal modeling, analysis and optimization of large-scale systems which evolve in time.  Thus, we have methods for approximation, sampling and control of these networks.  We have demonstrated the utility of our framework for system control via key application areas of interest such as cognitive radio, wireless body area sensing networks and vehicular networks.  Our methods can often offer perfect reconstruction of control algorithms with a reduction of 80% with respect to complexity.  We have also made novel connections between the visualization of an optimal control and image processing approaches which are well-suited to the use of graph signal processing.

Graph signal processing has been focused on general results valid for arbitrary graphs. We are the first to consider the specific characteristics of graphs built out of elementary finite state machines (FSMs), and the implication this has for computation, learning, sampling and representation. We are have also developed sparse approximation strategies tailored to FSMs with an emphasis on time-varying systems and the use of prior statistical information.  Our particular mathematical models for the networks are based on Markov chains.  Markov chains capture the temporal evoluation of the network (if my link is congested, my communication packet will be dropped; if my wireless channel is good, my communication packet will be received, etc. etc.).   Markov chains and graphs have been proposed as models for a staggering number of phenomena from biological systems , social networks, sensor networks, video systems, electricity supply, water systems, seismic processes etc. Thus, our methods have the potential to impact the study and design of a wide variety of sophisticated communication systems across many disciplines and research areas.

Our project has trained graduate students to integrate knowledge and understanding from diverse fields like communications, signal processing, optimization and controls to address theoretical as well as practical questions. Team members have been exposed to cutting edge research topics such as graph signal processing and sparse approximation methods. All of the graduate students on this project have presented their research in conference settings and within the group meetings.  The principal investigators have given numerous talks at universities and corporations, sharing the findings of this project.  The research has generated a number of published journal and conference articles.
